description:
Dacryopinax primogenitus is a species of fungus belonging to the phylum Basidiomycota. It is a jelly fungus, commonly known as the "first-born jelly fungus" or the "primordial jelly fungus."

The fungus produces gelatinous, orange-yellow to reddish-brown fruiting bodies that can reach up to 5 cm in diameter. The fruiting bodies have a trembling, gelatinous texture and a smooth, glossy surface. They typically grow in clusters on decaying wood, such as fallen logs or stumps, and are often found in temperate and subtropical forests.

Dacryopinax primogenitus is known for its ability to produce specialized structures called haustoria, which are used to penetrate and extract nutrients from the wood-decaying substrates it colonizes. This species plays a crucial role in the decomposition of woody plant material, contributing to the recycling of nutrients in forest ecosystems.

The fungus reproduces sexually through the production of basidiospores, which are dispersed by wind or water currents. The spores germinate and give rise to new mycelia, continuing the life cycle of this intriguing jelly fungus.
